five_facts: Native conifer found in high-elevation forests
Narrow, spire-like shape helps shed snow
Provides shelter for small mammals and birds
importance_to_ecosystem: Acts as a stabilizer in alpine forest communities and supports biodiversity by creating microclimates.

five_facts: Has sharp, square needles and papery cones
Bark provides nesting for insects and birds
importance_to_ecosystem: Key species in high-elevation ecosystems, providing food and habitat for diverse wildlife.

five_facts: Leaves tremble in the slightest breeze
Clonal colonies can live thousands of years
White bark is photosynthetic in winter
Rapidly regenerates after fire or avalanche
importance_to_ecosystem: Pioneer species after disturbance, critical for nutrient cycling and early-successional wildlife.

five_facts: Most widespread tree in the park
Straight trunks used historically for lodges
importance_to_ecosystem: Essential for forest regeneration, particularly after fire, and supports complex food webs.

five_facts: Edible berries consumed by humans and bears
Leaves turn brilliant colors in fall
importance_to_ecosystem: Vital berry-producing shrub in transitional zones; supports pollinators and omnivores.

five_facts: Grows in sunny meadows and sagebrush flats
importance_to_ecosystem: Improves soil fertility and supports pollinators across open habitats.

five_facts: One of the first wildflowers to bloom after snowmelt
importance_to_ecosystem: Critical early nectar source for bees and food source for deer in spring.

five_facts: Common in sagebrush and dry slopes
Deep taproot helps it survive drought
Native Americans used roots for medicine
Elk and deer graze on leaves
importance_to_ecosystem: One of the dominant flowering plants in drier zones; important forage plant.

five_facts: Unique flower with reflexed petals and shooting-star shape
Pink, purple, or magenta flowers in wet meadows
importance_to_ecosystem: Key nectar source during spring thaw in wetlands and ephemeral meadows.

five_facts: Silvery leaves and vibrant blue-purple flowers
Fixes nitrogen and improves soil structure
Toxic to livestock but beneficial to wildlife
importance_to_ecosystem: Plays a dual role in soil improvement and pollinator support in dry uplands.

five_facts: Yellow daisy-like flowers bloom in summer
Common along streams and wet meadows
Can form dense colonies in alpine zones
Leaves may be mildly toxic if ingested
importance_to_ecosystem: Provides nectar for butterflies and stabilizes wet meadow soils.
wildlife_value: Attracts butterflies and bees; occasionally grazed by deer and elk.

five_facts: Bright red bracts resemble a paintbrush
Semi-parasitic, drawing nutrients from neighboring plants
Color varies from red to orange depending on soil
Iconic wildflower of the Rocky Mountains
importance_to_ecosystem: Supports hummingbirds and insect pollinators; contributes to alpine biodiversity.
wildlife_value: Important nectar source for hummingbirds and bumblebees.

five_facts: Found in meadows, roadsides, and forests
importance_to_ecosystem: Provides nectar for pollinators and helps prevent erosion with fibrous roots.
wildlife_value: Attracts butterflies and beetles; some deer browse leaves.

five_facts: Tall stalks of bright pink flowers
importance_to_ecosystem: Stabilizes burned landscapes and attracts pollinators like bees and butterflies.
wildlife_value: Important for bees; young shoots may be browsed by elk and moose.

five_facts: Elegant blue and white flowers with long spurs
importance_to_ecosystem: Supports native pollinators and adds biodiversity to alpine and subalpine areas.
wildlife_value: Attracts hawk moths, butterflies, and bees.

five_facts: Tall stalks topped with dense white blooms
Leaves used by Native Americans for weaving
Can bloom en masse after fire
importance_to_ecosystem: Provides nectar to a range of pollinators and stabilizes soil in montane zones.
wildlife_value: Grizzly bears occasionally feed on roots; attracts insects.

five_facts: Dominant shrub in drier areas of the park
Crucial winter food for mule deer and pronghorn
importance_to_ecosystem: Supports an entire ecosystem; foundational species for sage-steppe communities.
wildlife_value: Primary winter browse for deer, elk, and sage grouse habitat.

five_facts: Bright pink-purple blooms in wet areas
Grows near seeps, springs, and alpine streams
Vulnerable to trampling in popular areas
importance_to_ecosystem: Supports high-elevation pollinators and contributes to biodiversity in wet alpine zones.

five_facts: Golden daisy-like flowers with heart-shaped leaves
Used medicinally for pain and swelling
Prefers shady forests and open woodlands
importance_to_ecosystem: Provides ground cover and erosion control on forest floors.
wildlife_value: Pollinated by flies and bees; rarely browsed by ungulates.

five_facts: Bright pink flowers with sticky stems
Leaves turn deep red in fall
Tolerates varied moisture and sun levels
importance_to_ecosystem: Major contributor to summer pollinator networks in open habitats.
wildlife_value: Frequented by bees, butterflies, and hoverflies.
